Ø­Ø¨ÙØ¨ Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ | image = | order = [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Minister of Interior of Egypt]] | president = [[Hosni Mubarak]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1938|03|1}} | birth_place = Egypt | term_start = 1997 | term_end = 31 January 2011 | predecessor = [[Hassan al-Alfi]] | successor = [[Mahmoud Wagdy]] | party = [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)]] }} '''Habib Ibrahim el-Adly''' ({{lang-ar|Ø­Ø¨ÙØ¨ Ø¥Ø¨Ø±Ø§ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ}}) (born March 1, 1938) is a former Egyptian politician. He served as an Interior Minister of [[Egypt]] from 1997 to 2011. ==Biography== El-Adly graduated from the police academy in 1961. In 1965 he joined the [[State Security Investigations Service]]. After working at various investigation departments, he was employed at the Foreign Ministry from 1982 to 1984. He then investigated state security matters, and became assistant interior minister in 1993.http://www.sis.gov.eg/En/Politics/Executive/Ministries/040804000000000016.htm Egypt State Information Service He replaced General Hassan al-Alfi as interior minister after the [[November 1997 Luxor massacre]].{{cite news | url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60A10FE3F5F0C738EDDA80994DF494D81 | title = Shake-Up in Cairo Follows Tourists' Killings | date = November 20, 1997 | work = New York Times}} He was replaced by [[Mahmoud Wagdy]] on January 31, 2011, as part of a cabinet reshuffle aimed at appeasing the mass protests during [[2011 Egyptian revolution]].{{cite web | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011131132324475241.html | title = Mubarak swears in new cabinet | date = January 31, 2011 | work = Al-Jazeera}} During the uprising, the Egyptian Attorney General announced el-Adly had been given a travel ban.[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201123142759661467.html Egypt bans ex-ministers from travel] Al-Jazeera. 03 Feb 2011 Following Hosni Mubarak's resignation, el-Adly and two other former ministers were arrested on corruption charges.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12500968 Egypt after Mubarak: Three ex-ministers arrested] BBC News. 17 February 2011 He is reported to be facing charges of fraud, [[money laundering]] and for ordering that security forces fire on demonstrators during the early days of the protests.Shalaby, Ahmed. [http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/dismissed-interior-minister-be-investigated-soon-say-judicial-sources Dismissed interior minister to be investigated soon, say judicial sources] al-Masry al-Youm. 17 February 2011 If convicted, el-Adly could face the [[Capital punishment|death penalty]]. Additionally, el-Adly's assets were ordered frozen by a court order.Finnan, David [http://www.english.rfi.fr/africa/20110217-cairo-court-orders-former-interior-minister-adlys-assets-be-seized Cairo court orders former Interior Minister Adly's assets seized] Radio France Internationale 17 February 2011 El-Adly is estimated to have amassed a fortune of 1.2 billion US dollars.[http://www.smh.com.au/executive-style/luxury/hosni-mubaraks-estimated-70-billion-fortune-makes-him-richer-than-carlos-slim-and-bill-gates-20110215-1atxm.html Hosni Mubarak's estimated $70 billion fortune makes him richer than Carlos Slim and Bill Gates] He pleaded not guilty to corruption charges on 5 March 2011, answering questions by the judge on whether he had illegally profited from his government position or laundered money by saying "that did not happen."MacFarquhar, Neil. Stack, Liam. [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/06/world/middleeast/06egypt.html Ex-Security Chief Hauled to Court as Egyptians Storm His Compound] ''New York Times'', 5 March 2011. On 5 May, 2011, el-Adly was found guilty of fraud and money laundering and was sentenced to 12 years in prison. He still faces a trial and a possible death penalty for ordering police to use live ammunition on protesters.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13292322 Egypt ex-minister Habib al-Adly jailed for 12 years] BBC News. 5 May 2011 == See also == * [[Cabinet of Egypt]] * [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.egyptiancabinet.gov.eg/ The Cabinet of Egypt] Official site of the Egyptian cabinet. * [http://www.sis.gov.eg/En/Politics/Executive/Ministries/040804000000000016.htm Habib Ibrahim El Adly profile] Egypt State Information Service {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Hassan al-Alfi]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Minister of Interior]]|years=1997 - 2011}} {{s-aft|after=[[Mahmoud Wagdy]]}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata | NAME = Adly El, Habib Ibrahim | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Interior Minister of Egypt from 1997 to 2011 | DATE OF BIRTH = March 1, 1938 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Egypt | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Adly el, Habib Ibrahim}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Egyptian prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Egyptian Sunni Muslims]] [[Category:Interior Ministers of Egypt]] [[Category:Money launderers]] [[Category:National Democratic Party (Egypt) politicians]] [[Category:People convicted of fraud]] [[Category:People from Cairo]] [[Category:People of the 2011 Egyptian revolution]] [[Category:Politicians convicted of crimes]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of Egypt]] {{MEast-mil-bio-stub}} {{Africa-mil-bio-stub}} {{Egypt-politician-stub}} [[ar:Ø­Ø¨ÙØ¨ Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ]] [[de:Habib al-Adli]] [[fr:Habib el-Adli]] [[it:Habib al-'Adli]] [[he:×××× ××-×¢××××]]
